I‚Äôve been an active and trusted developer on Fiverr for a long time, with consistently 5-star ratings from all my clients and a proven track record of delivering high-quality work. However, it‚Äôs incredibly disappointing to see that Fiverr‚Äôs platform doesn‚Äôt seem to value or rank skilled professionals properly. Despite my positive reviews and strong client feedback, my gig still doesn‚Äôt appear among the top results. Meanwhile, many gigs that use copied images or misleading content are ranked above genuine creators like me. It‚Äôs frustrating to see that quality and authenticity are not being prioritized. On top of that, Fiverr‚Äôs commission structure is very high taking around 25%, compared to competitors like Upwork, which only charges 10%. This makes it harder for real professionals to sustain their business on this platform. Additionally, the customer support is painfully slow. I‚Äôve applied for Freelancer Pro and Vetted Pro, and after submitting my applications, I sent follow-up emails as well. Yet, I‚Äôve received no response at all. This lack of communication and support has only made me more disillusioned with the platform. Day by day, my confidence in Fiverr continues to decline, and I‚Äôm finding it harder to justify staying on the platform. Fiverr needs to improve its ranking algorithms to prioritize genuine talent, reduce commission fees, and actually support its top-tier freelancers. If these issues aren‚Äôt addressed soon, many dedicated professionals might start looking for alternative platforms where their work and commitment are truly valued.

1. Concerns Regarding the Success Score System While I understand the value of having a performance metric like the Success Score to maintain quality standards on the platform, I believe the current system may have some inconsistencies or issues that need attention. Despite maintaining strong client satisfaction, timely deliveries, professional communication, and zero cancellations, my Success Score has been dropping without a clear explanation. This not only confuses but also creates unnecessary stress for freelancers who are doing everything right but are unable to understand where they are going wrong. I kindly request that Fiverr provide transparent and detailed insights into the criteria that influence the Success Score. If freelancers are expected to improve, they need to know exactly what factors affect their score and how they can take actionable steps to address them. Otherwise, showing a declining score with no guidance or control leaves sellers demotivated and in the dark. 2. Limited Opportunities for New Sellers Another critical concern is the lack of visibility and opportunities for new sellers on the platform. Many of us join Fiverr with the intention of working hard, building a career, and earning a stable income. Still, unfortunately, it has become increasingly difficult to get any traction as a new freelancer. New sellers are often not shown to clients, making it nearly impossible to receive orders organically. If they are expected to bring clients from outside Fiverr to the platform, then the value proposition of Fiverr diminishes, especially considering that Fiverr takes a commission, while some other platforms (like Upwork) do not charge for externally sourced clients. Additionally, the lack of features such as bidding on jobs or applying to postings, especially when such opportunities are only available to top-rated sellers, puts new freelancers at a severe disadvantage. If no one gives them a chance, how are they supposed to grow, earn, and eventually become top-rated themselves? Final Thoughts Fiverr has the potential to be a fair and empowering marketplace for freelancers at all levels. However, the current systems seem to disproportionately favor established sellers while making it extremely hard for new or growing freelancers to find their footing. My suggestions: Make the Success Score criteria transparent and actionable. Provide better visibility and chances for new sellers, especially those who demonstrate professionalism and quality. Consider fee flexibility for clients sourced externally. Introduce or expand job bidding features to give everyone a fair shot, not just top-rated sellers. I hope Fiverr takes this feedback constructively and makes improvements that support all freelancers, both new and experienced. Thank you for your time and for continuously working to improve the platform.

Earlier this month, I shared my experience as a beginner on Fiverr. I now want to share the conclusion of that experience, after hoping for a better outcome. There are several reasons why I feel compelled to write this review. You be the judge! To warn beginners: Be very careful and learn from my costly experience. I waited, trying not to penalize my editor and hoping to remain professional as always. I gave her, Quata D. Merit, time, hoping to find a compromise. I had already informed customer support, telling them I believed she knew what she was doing after all her years on the site. I trusted the reviews and the star rating, and I honestly don‚Äôt understand what went wrong. Is the rating system really as reliable as we think? I had expected more than one pass at my manuscript, but that wasn‚Äôt the case. Fiverr customer support clarified: "In this case, the freelancer offers a 'deep edit,' which is what they seem to have done for your manuscript." Wow‚Äîwhat a deep statement! My editor read my manuscript once and then said goodbye and added ‚ÄúIf you want another quote, let me know." This was for a 77,000-word manuscript, with many suggested changes, but no follow-up. I never expected the editor to reread the entire manuscript. However, confirming the changes would have been the next logical step, as I read somewhere, before proceeding on Fiverr. I really don‚Äôt know what else to say about this experience. Customer service kept asking me what I wanted to do, but I received conflicting answers from different representatives. One would say one thing, the next would say something else. It was unclear why they didn‚Äôt mention the 14-day rule from the start. It feels like they were trying to push the matter past the 14-day window, rather than giving me clear information upfront. In the end, I lost my money, and worse, I‚Äôm nowhere near finished with my manuscript. When I joined Fiverr, I hoped that the unknown road ahead as a new writer would be easier, but this experience has made it much harder. I sincerely hope your experience is a better one!

I am in complete awe that a company of this magnitude can have such disgraceful customer service and contact options. I will clearly describe some of their false claims and how terrible my experience with them has been. Firstly, I'm from the UK, have been in the freelance industry for multiple years and have multiple successful freelance accounts on other platforms (Upwork, PeoplePerHour etc). I have been aware of Fiverr for years and wary of it's place at the bottom of the freelancing heap, and now I know why for good reason. Now my idea of branching out has led me to uncover a huge degree of ineptness and in my opinion systematic manipulation in their business. In setting up my account, I follow the exact steps I have many times before on other platforms. Everything is going fine until I hit their verification step. Firstly, all my details are accepted (UK driving licence, phone number, tax details etc). Now I'll be the first to admit the lighting in my room isn't the best, and this has caused issues before with verification on other platforms. I unfortunately fail this verification with it being unable to see my face clearly, then that's it, no more chances. I think no big deal, I'll reach out to their customer service, a company like this must have a good system in place to solve easy mistakes such as this. With one click of a button like in other sites, they can reset the verification and I can be fully confirmed just a few hours later. Now this is where the sheer audacity of planned ineptness, laziness or straight up terrible customer service/ disregard for a system comes into play. Firstly, I'm very happy to discover they have a live chatbot, like any respectable company with a clientele such as theirs should have. The use of the chatbot is clearly plastered all over their advertising as a KPI of solving queries and getting in contact with a member of their team. Little do people know this is actually impossible. 30 minutes later, infinitely more frustrated and having tried every option, I can see this in an impossibility and is simply there for show. I have taken screenshots and copied the call log to prove this point. It gets to a stage each time with enough prompts to say that it will get you in contact with someone, but this never materialises. This setting simply isn't connected. Now don't get me wrong, this may work for those who have already been verified/ accepted, I haven't checked. But now I wouldn't put it past them to have something like this hardcoded into their system that those without verification cannot even access support. The help centre, was my natural next port of call. As you can guess this leads absolutely nowhere and offers no help for you to get in contact with a human who can fix my issue in 2 seconds. As a last resort you then reach out to their email support. I think amazing .. this is accompanied by a proud banner stating that the "email customer service responds to all enquiries within 12 hours", wow what a saving grace. I gladly write up my polite, easy to read email explaining the issue and a few hours later I'm met with the following message: "Hi there, Thank you for reaching out to us about this issue. We understand you tried to open a Seller profile on Fiverr, and received our response explaining your request wasn't approved. You're welcome to continue using Fiverr as a buyer. If there is anything else we can help you with, please let us know." Now by this point, I am not a happy bunny. I go off and find multiple threads from over a whole year ago echoing my exact problem and inability to contact their customer service. So not only are they sending out template responses en masse and claiming to "respond" to all email queries, they've been getting away with this for over a whole year!! How has nobody else spotted this and how wrong this is. Any hopeful people reaching out who may need what this site offers more than I will be met with this blanket, ill-thought response. As I said before, I genuinely think this is disgraceful and just pure laziness on their side. This can only be summarised as a systematic approach to frustrate the consumer enough to call defeat after exhausting the only 3 avenues available, all of which have been cleverly manipulated so as not to be viable at all. If but one person reads this and becomes aware of why their application is going so terribly, then I will be content. Just know if you do, it is not your fault and you are a victim of something which has clearly been orchestrated. Fiverr, shame on you. One of the aspects I truly appreciated about Fiverr is the platform's accessibility. It provides a fantastic opportunity for freelancers like myself to showcase our skills and connect with clients from all over the world. The user-friendly interface makes it easy to set up a profile, list services, and manage orders. I also enjoyed the diverse range of projects available, which allowed me to work on various design styles and expand my portfolio. Additionally, the rating and review system is a great feature. I found that positive feedback from clients significantly boosted my confidence and motivated me to deliver high-quality work. On the flip side, one challenge I encountered was the level of competition. With so many talented designers on the platform, it can be difficult to stand out, especially when starting. I believe Fiverr could enhance its support for new sellers by offering more resources or promotional opportunities to help them gain visibility. Another area for improvement is the communication tools. While the messaging system is functional, it could benefit from additional features, such as file sharing capabilities or integrated video calls, to facilitate clearer communication between freelancers and clients. Fiverr excels in providing a global marketplace that connects freelancers with clients seeking specific services. The variety of categories and the ability to customize gigs allow for a tailored experience that meets diverse client needs. The platform's commitment to secure transactions and timely payments is also commendable, as it fosters trust between freelancers and clients. To further enhance the experience for freelancers, Fiverr could consider implementing a mentorship program or community forums where experienced sellers can share tips and advice with newcomers. Additionally, offering more educational resources, such as webinars or tutorials on marketing and branding, could empower freelancers to better promote their services and improve their chances of success. Overall, my experience on Fiverr has been positive, and I appreciate the opportunities it has provided me as a graphic designer. With a few enhancements, I believe it can become an even more valuable platform for freelancers and clients alike.

Fiverr is best for established sellers. It's difficult to get hired if you're not already established. Also, I've had errors with the system where I haven't been emailed when a new client messages me on Fiverr. Meanwhile, if you miss a message or take too long to respond, it increases your response time, which makes you look bad as a seller. But if you don't have anyone contact you for weeks at a time, you stop looking at it daily. Then, if the system doesn't email you about a new message, you're hosed. The system also seems to punish you if you take a vacation and shut your gigs off for a week--it seems to make it so you don't get new business as easily. The other drawback is that, at least so far (2 years in), I've had to work for far, far less than I'm worth. Then they take 20% from the seller and some percentage (5%, I think) from the buyer. So they're get a huge, greedy cut. Ten percent would be reasonable, in my opinion. Twenty percent is greedy, especially when they're also collecting an additional percentage from your clients. Additionally, they hold on to your money for two weeks, so they get two weeks of interest on every payment made, which earns them even more money. So they make money hand over fist, while you make pennies. On the positive end, it's easy to withdraw your money and see your earnings. You're also guaranteed to get paid for your work--it's set up so clients can't stiff you. So that's good. Overall, it's good if you really need some extra cash. You'll make some here and there. But if you have other money-making alternatives, those options may be better. Note that I'm using a different email address for this review than I use for Fiverr because I don't want Fiverr to punish me for it.

Fiverr's level system is one of the most flawed aspects of the platform, especially for freelancers. While it aims to reward performance, it often fails to recognize true expertise. Many low-skilled accounts manage to rank and secure clients, while a significant number of highly skilled professionals struggle to get enough visibility, sometimes waiting over six months or more without substantial client interaction. The introduction of the paid promotion system for gigs is a mixed bag. While it can help some freelancers gain visibility, it often comes at a steep cost‚Äîsometimes consuming up to 80% of their profit margins. Additionally, the system is inconsistent; while it may generate one or two orders, it frequently targets the wrong audience, resulting in wasted clicks and unproductive expenses.
